canonical_explanation.text: India is a large country in South Asia with diverse physical features. The Himalayas in the north are the youngest and highest mountain range in the world, with Mount Everest being the tallest peak. South of the Himalayas lies the Indo-Gangetic Plain, one of the most fertile plains in the world, formed by rivers like the Ganga, Yamuna, and Brahmaputra. The Deccan Plateau is a large, triangular plateau in southern India, bounded by the Western Ghats and Eastern Ghats. The Thar Desert in western Rajasthan is a hot, sandy desert. India has long coastlines along the Arabian Sea in the west and the Bay of Bengal in the east. Major rivers include the Ganga, Yamuna, Brahmaputra, Godavari, Krishna, Narmada, and Kaveri. India has three main seasons: summer (March-June), monsoon/rainy season (July-September), and winter (October-February). India has 28 states and 8 Union Territories. It shares borders with Pakistan, China, Nepal, Bhutan, Bangladesh, Myanmar, and is close to Sri Lanka across the Palk Strait.
rules: India is in South Asia, the seventh largest country in the world
Himalayas: young fold mountains in the north, Mount Everest is the highest peak (8,849 m)
Indo-Gangetic Plain: very fertile, formed by Ganga, Yamuna, Brahmaputra rivers
Deccan Plateau: large triangular plateau in southern India, between Western and Eastern Ghats
Thar Desert: hot sandy desert in western Rajasthan
Major rivers: Ganga, Yamuna, Brahmaputra, Godavari, Krishna, Narmada, Kaveri
Coastlines: Arabian Sea (west), Bay of Bengal (east), Indian Ocean (south)
Three main seasons: summer, monsoon (rainy), winter
India has 28 states and 8 Union Territories
Neighbouring countries: Pakistan, China, Nepal, Bhutan, Bangladesh, Myanmar, Sri Lanka

questions.question_text: Which mountain range is located in the north of India?
questions.explanation_correct: The Himalayas are the great mountain range in northern India. They stretch across the northern border of India and are the youngest and highest mountain range in the world. They protect India from cold winds from Central Asia.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Himalayas are in northern India. The Aravalli Range is in Rajasthan and is one of the oldest mountain ranges. The Western Ghats run along the western coast and the Eastern Ghats along the eastern coast of India.

questions.question_text: What is the highest peak in the world?
questions.explanation_correct: Mount Everest is the highest peak in the world at 8,849 metres. It is located in the Himalayas, on the border between Nepal and Tibet (China). Kanchenjunga, the third highest peak, is partly in India (Sikkim).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mount Everest (8,849 m) is the world's highest peak. K2 (8,611 m) is the second highest, Kanchenjunga (8,586 m) the third, and Nanda Devi (7,816 m) is the highest peak entirely within India.

questions.question_text: The Indo-Gangetic Plain is known for being:

options.text: One of the most fertile plains in the world

questions.explanation_correct: The Indo-Gangetic Plain is one of the most fertile plains in the world. It was formed by the soil (alluvium) deposited by rivers like the Ganga, Yamuna, and Brahmaputra. It is the most densely populated region of India and produces a lot of food grains.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Indo-Gangetic Plain is extremely fertile, not a desert or mountain region. Rivers like the Ganga and Yamuna have deposited rich soil over thousands of years, making it ideal for farming. It is India's major food-producing area.

questions.question_text: The Thar Desert is located in which state of India?
questions.explanation_correct: The Thar Desert, also called the Great Indian Desert, is in western Rajasthan. It is a hot and sandy desert with extreme temperatures. Despite the harsh conditions, people, plants, and animals have adapted to live there.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Thar Desert is in Rajasthan, western India. Kerala is a lush green state in the south, Tamil Nadu is also in the south, and Assam is in the northeast. The Thar is the only large desert in India.

questions.question_text: The Deccan Plateau is located in:
questions.explanation_correct: The Deccan Plateau is a large, triangular plateau in southern India. It is bounded by the Western Ghats on the west, the Eastern Ghats on the east, and the Satpura and Vindhya ranges in the north. It covers much of central and southern India.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Deccan Plateau is in southern India, not in the north or exclusively in the east or west. It is a large elevated area shaped like a triangle, with the Western Ghats and Eastern Ghats on either side.

questions.question_text: The Himalayas protect India from the cold winds blowing from Central Asia.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. The Himalayas act as a natural barrier, blocking the cold winds from Central Asia. They also block the monsoon winds from moving northward, causing heavy rainfall on the Indian side. Without the Himalayas, India would be much colder.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. The Himalayas are like a giant wall that protects India from icy winds from the north. They also play a key role in India's monsoon by trapping moisture-laden winds, leading to rainfall.

questions.question_text: Ramesh lives in a flat area near a river where farmers grow rice, wheat, and sugarcane. He most likely lives in the:
questions.explanation_correct: A flat area near rivers where rice, wheat, and sugarcane are grown describes the Indo-Gangetic Plain. It is the most fertile region of India, watered by major rivers, and is the main agricultural area of the country.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The description matches the Indo-Gangetic Plain, which is flat, near major rivers, and highly fertile. The Thar Desert is dry and sandy, the Himalayas are mountainous, and while the Deccan Plateau has farming, it is elevated.

questions.question_text: Which physical feature of India is correctly described?

options.text: The Thar Desert receives the heaviest rainfall in India
The Himalayas are the oldest mountains in India
The Indo-Gangetic Plain is formed by alluvial soil deposited by rivers
The Deccan Plateau is in northern India

questions.explanation_correct: The Indo-Gangetic Plain is formed by alluvial soil (rich, fertile soil) deposited by rivers like the Ganga, Yamuna, and Brahmaputra over thousands of years. The Thar Desert is dry, the Himalayas are young mountains, and the Deccan Plateau is in southern India.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Indo-Gangetic Plain is formed by alluvial deposits from rivers. The Thar is one of the driest places (not the wettest). The Himalayas are the youngest (not oldest) mountains. The Aravalli Range is the oldest. The Deccan Plateau is in southern India.

questions.question_text: Which is the longest river of India?
questions.explanation_correct: The Ganga is the longest river in India, flowing about 2,525 kilometres. It originates from the Gangotri glacier in the Himalayas and flows through Uttarakhand, Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, and West Bengal before emptying into the Bay of Bengal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Ganga (about 2,525 km) is the longest river in India. The Godavari (about 1,465 km) is the longest river in Peninsular India. The Yamuna is a major tributary of the Ganga, and the Narmada flows westward into the Arabian Sea.

questions.question_text: Which river is known as the 'Ganga of the South'?
questions.explanation_correct: The Godavari is called the 'Ganga of the South' because it is the longest river in Peninsular India (about 1,465 km). It flows through Maharashtra, Telangana, and Andhra Pradesh before emptying into the Bay of Bengal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Godavari is called the Ganga of the South. It is the longest river in the Deccan region. The Krishna and Kaveri are also important southern rivers, and the Narmada flows through central India into the Arabian Sea.

questions.question_text: The Brahmaputra river flows through which part of India?
questions.explanation_correct: The Brahmaputra is one of India's major rivers, flowing through the state of Assam in northeastern India. It originates in Tibet and enters India through Arunachal Pradesh. It is one of the widest rivers in India and often causes floods in Assam.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Brahmaputra flows through Assam in northeastern India. It is one of the largest rivers in the world. It originates in Tibet, enters India through Arunachal Pradesh, flows through Assam, and joins the Ganga in Bangladesh.

questions.question_text: The Narmada and Tapi are the only two major rivers in India that flow westward into the Arabian Sea.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Most major Indian rivers flow eastward into the Bay of Bengal. The Narmada and Tapi (Tapti) are the two major rivers that flow westward into the Arabian Sea. This makes them unique among India's peninsular rivers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. While most of India's major rivers (Ganga, Godavari, Krishna, Kaveri) flow eastward, the Narmada and Tapi are special because they flow westward into the Arabian Sea.

questions.question_text: Rivers are important for India because they:

options.text: Provide water for farming, drinking, transportation, and support wildlife

questions.explanation_correct: Rivers are vital for India. They provide water for farming (irrigation), drinking, and industries. They support transport and fishing. Rich soil deposited by rivers makes farmland fertile. Rivers also support diverse wildlife and are culturally sacred in India.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rivers serve many purposes beyond just drinking water. They irrigate farmland, support transportation, generate electricity (hydropower), provide fish, deposit fertile soil, and sustain ecosystems. They are essential for India's economy and life.

questions.question_text: Which river flows through the city of Delhi?
questions.explanation_correct: The Yamuna river flows through Delhi. It is the largest tributary of the Ganga and originates from the Yamunotri glacier in the Himalayas. It also flows through cities like Agra (where the Taj Mahal is located) and Mathura.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Yamuna flows through Delhi. The Ganga flows through cities like Varanasi and Kolkata. The Godavari flows through Maharashtra and Andhra Pradesh. The Kaveri flows through Karnataka and Tamil Nadu.

questions.question_text: How many main seasons does India have?
questions.explanation_correct: India has three main seasons: summer (March-June, hot weather), monsoon or rainy season (July-September, heavy rains), and winter (October-February, cold weather). The monsoon season is very important for India's agriculture.
questions.explanation_incorrect: India has three main seasons: summer (hot), monsoon (rainy), and winter (cold). Unlike countries with four seasons, India's climate is greatly influenced by the monsoon, which brings the crucial rainy season.

questions.question_text: The monsoon season in India brings:
questions.explanation_correct: The monsoon season (July-September) brings heavy rainfall to most parts of India. This rain is crucial for agriculture as most Indian farmers depend on monsoon rains to grow crops. Without the monsoon, India would face severe droughts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The monsoon brings heavy rainfall, not snow or extreme cold. Monsoon rains are the lifeline of Indian agriculture. Most farmers in India depend on monsoon rain for their crops. A weak monsoon can lead to drought and food shortages.

questions.question_text: Cherrapunji in Meghalaya receives some of the heaviest rainfall in the world. This is because:

options.text: Monsoon winds carry moisture from the Bay of Bengal and are blocked by the hills
People in Cherrapunji pray for rain

questions.explanation_correct: Cherrapunji (Sohra) and nearby Mawsynram receive extremely heavy rainfall because monsoon winds carrying moisture from the Bay of Bengal are forced upward by the Khasi Hills. As the air rises, it cools and releases massive amounts of rain.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cherrapunji receives heavy rain because moisture-laden monsoon winds from the Bay of Bengal hit the Khasi Hills and are forced upward. This causes the air to cool and drop its moisture as heavy rain. Geography and monsoon winds together cause this extreme rainfall.

questions.question_text: The Thar Desert receives very heavy rainfall during the monsoon season.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. The Thar Desert receives very little rainfall, even during the monsoon season. The monsoon winds lose most of their moisture before reaching the desert. The Thar gets less than 250 mm of rain per year, making it one of the driest places in India.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is false. The Thar Desert is one of the driest regions in India because the monsoon winds lose most of their moisture before they reach western Rajasthan. It gets very little rain compared to the rest of India.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly describes India's summer season?

options.text: It lasts from October to February and is very cold
It lasts from March to June and is very hot
It lasts from July to September and has heavy rain

questions.explanation_correct: India's summer season is from March to June. It is the hottest time of the year, with temperatures reaching above 45°C in some parts. The period from October to February is winter, and July to September is the monsoon (rainy) season.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Summer in India is from March to June (hot). Winter is from October to February (cold). The monsoon season is July to September (rainy). Each season has its own characteristics and importance.

questions.question_text: How many states does India have?
questions.explanation_correct: India has 28 states and 8 Union Territories. The states are governed by their own state governments, while Union Territories are directly governed by the central government. Each state has its own capital city.
questions.explanation_incorrect: India currently has 28 states and 8 Union Territories, making a total of 36 administrative divisions. Earlier India had 29 states, but Jammu and Kashmir was reorganised into two Union Territories in 2019.

questions.question_text: How many Union Territories does India have?
questions.explanation_correct: India has 8 Union Territories: Delhi, Chandigarh, Puducherry, Andaman and Nicobar Islands, Lakshadweep, Dadra and Nagar Haveli and Daman and Diu, Ladakh, and Jammu and Kashmir. Union Territories are directly governed by the central government.
questions.explanation_incorrect: India has 8 Union Territories. They include Delhi, Chandigarh, Puducherry, Andaman and Nicobar Islands, Lakshadweep, Dadra and Nagar Haveli and Daman and Diu, Ladakh, and Jammu and Kashmir.

questions.question_text: Which is the largest state in India by area?
questions.explanation_correct: Rajasthan is the largest state in India by area. It covers about 342,239 square kilometres and is located in western India. It includes the Thar Desert and the Aravalli Range. Jaipur is its capital city.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rajasthan is the largest state by area. Uttar Pradesh is the most populated state. Madhya Pradesh is the second largest by area, and Maharashtra is the third largest. Rajasthan's large area includes the Thar Desert.

questions.question_text: The capital of Rajasthan is _____ and the capital of Kerala is _____.
questions.explanation_correct: Jaipur is the capital of Rajasthan, also known as the 'Pink City'. Thiruvananthapuram (Trivandrum) is the capital of Kerala. Each of India's 28 states has its own capital city where the state government is headquartered.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The capitals are Jaipur (Rajasthan) and Thiruvananthapuram (Kerala). Udaipur, Jodhpur, and Jaisalmer are other cities in Rajasthan. Kochi, Calicut, and Thrissur are other cities in Kerala.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a Union Territory, not a state?
questions.explanation_correct: Delhi is a Union Territory (officially the National Capital Territory of Delhi), not a state. Although Delhi has its own government, it is directly governed by the central government. Goa, Sikkim, and Meghalaya are all states.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Delhi is a Union Territory, not a state. Goa is India's smallest state by area, Sikkim is a state in the northeast, and Meghalaya is also a northeastern state. Union Territories are governed directly by the central government.

questions.question_text: Which is the smallest state in India by area?
questions.explanation_correct: Goa is the smallest state in India by area. It is located on the western coast and is famous for its beautiful beaches. Despite its small size, Goa has a rich history and culture, with Portuguese influence lasting over 450 years.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Goa is the smallest state by area in India. Sikkim is the least populous state. Tripura and Mizoram are small northeastern states but larger than Goa. Goa's capital is Panaji.

questions.question_text: Which country borders India to the northwest?
questions.explanation_correct: Pakistan borders India to the northwest. The border between India and Pakistan is called the Radcliffe Line. Bangladesh borders India to the east, Myanmar to the northeast, and Bhutan to the north (between Sikkim and Assam).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pakistan is to India's northwest. Bangladesh is to the east, Myanmar is to the northeast, and Bhutan is to the north. India shares its longest land border with Bangladesh and its border with Pakistan is the second longest.

questions.question_text: India is located in which continent?
questions.explanation_correct: India is located in Asia, specifically in South Asia. It is the seventh largest country in the world and the second most populous. India is surrounded by the Indian Ocean to the south, the Arabian Sea to the west, and the Bay of Bengal to the east.
questions.explanation_incorrect: India is in Asia, specifically in the South Asian subcontinent. Asia is the largest continent in the world. India's neighbours Pakistan, Nepal, Bhutan, Bangladesh, Myanmar, and Sri Lanka are also in Asia.

questions.question_text: Which country is India's neighbour to the north, separated by the Himalayas?
questions.explanation_correct: China borders India to the north, with the Himalayas forming a natural boundary between the two countries. China is also the most populous country in the world. Nepal and Bhutan are also located between India and China in the Himalayan region.
questions.explanation_incorrect: China is India's neighbour to the north, separated by the Himalayas. Sri Lanka is an island nation to the south. Pakistan is to the northwest, and Bangladesh is to the east.

questions.question_text: Sri Lanka is separated from India by a narrow strip of sea called the:
questions.explanation_correct: Sri Lanka is separated from India by the Palk Strait, a narrow strip of sea. Sri Lanka is an island nation located to the southeast of India. It is the closest maritime neighbour of India, separated by just about 30 kilometres at the narrowest point.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Palk Strait separates India from Sri Lanka. The Bay of Bengal is to the east of India, the Arabian Sea to the west, and the Indian Ocean to the south. The Palk Strait is a very narrow body of water between Tamil Nadu and Sri Lanka.

questions.question_text: Nepal and Bhutan are India's neighbouring countries located in the Himalayan region.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Nepal and Bhutan are both small countries located in the Himalayan region, between India and China. Nepal is known as the 'Land of Everest', and Bhutan is known as the 'Land of the Thunder Dragon'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. Both Nepal and Bhutan are located in the Himalayas and share borders with India. Nepal is to the north of Uttar Pradesh and Bihar, and Bhutan is between Sikkim and Assam.

questions.question_text: The Western Ghats and Eastern Ghats are mountain ranges that border the:
questions.explanation_correct: The Western Ghats and Eastern Ghats border the Deccan Plateau. The Western Ghats run along the western coast of India (taller and continuous), and the Eastern Ghats run along the eastern coast (lower and broken). Together, they form the edges of the triangular Deccan Plateau.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Western and Eastern Ghats border the Deccan Plateau, not the Indo-Gangetic Plain, Thar Desert, or Himalayas. The Western Ghats are on the west side and the Eastern Ghats on the east side of the Deccan Plateau.

questions.question_text: Which river is considered the holiest river in India and flows through Varanasi?
questions.explanation_correct: The Ganga is considered the holiest river in India. It flows through the ancient city of Varanasi (Kashi), where millions of pilgrims come for sacred rituals. The Ganga is culturally and spiritually significant to millions of Indians.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Ganga flows through Varanasi and is considered the holiest river in India. Varanasi is one of the oldest cities in the world and a major religious and cultural centre. The Ganga's banks in Varanasi have famous ghats (steps).

questions.question_text: The capital of India is:
questions.explanation_correct: New Delhi is the capital of India. It is located in the National Capital Territory of Delhi and is the seat of the central government, Parliament, and the President's official residence (Rashtrapati Bhavan).
questions.explanation_incorrect: New Delhi is the capital of India. Mumbai is the financial capital, Kolkata was the capital during British rule, and Chennai is the capital of Tamil Nadu. New Delhi has been India's capital since 1911.

questions.question_text: The Kaveri river flows through the states of _____ and _____.
questions.explanation_correct: The Kaveri (Cauvery) river flows through Karnataka and Tamil Nadu. It originates in the Western Ghats at Talakaveri in Karnataka and empties into the Bay of Bengal in Tamil Nadu. It is an important river for irrigation in both states.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Kaveri river flows through Karnataka and Tamil Nadu. It is sometimes called the 'Ganga of the South' along with the Godavari. The Krishna flows through Maharashtra, Karnataka, and Andhra Pradesh.

questions.question_text: India has diverse physical features — mountains, plains, plateaus, deserts, and coasts. How does this diversity help India?

options.text: It does not help at all
It supports different types of agriculture, wildlife, and livelihoods across regions
It makes travel difficult so it is a disadvantage

questions.explanation_correct: India's diverse physical features are a great advantage. Mountains provide water and timber, plains support agriculture, plateaus have minerals, coasts provide fish, and deserts have unique ecosystems. This diversity supports different types of farming, industries, and lifestyles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: India's diverse geography is a strength. Different regions support different activities: the plains grow crops, mountains provide water and tourism, coasts support fishing, and plateaus have minerals. This variety makes India self-sufficient in many ways.

questions.question_text: India shares its border with how many countries?
questions.explanation_correct: India shares its land border with 7 countries: Pakistan (northwest), China (north), Nepal (north), Bhutan (northeast), Bangladesh (east), Myanmar (east), and Afghanistan (a small border in the northwest, through Pakistan-occupied Kashmir). Sri Lanka is separated by sea.
questions.explanation_incorrect: India shares land borders with 7 countries: Pakistan, China, Nepal, Bhutan, Bangladesh, Myanmar, and Afghanistan. Sri Lanka and Maldives are maritime (sea) neighbours. India's central location in South Asia gives it many neighbours.

questions.question_text: Why is the monsoon season so important for Indian farmers?

options.text: Because farmers do not work during the monsoon
Because most crops depend on monsoon rains for water, and irrigation is limited
Because the monsoon brings cold weather
Because farmers celebrate festivals during the monsoon

questions.explanation_correct: The monsoon is crucial because a large portion of Indian farmland depends on rain rather than irrigation. The monsoon provides the water needed to grow major crops like rice, wheat, and pulses. A weak monsoon can cause drought and crop failure, affecting millions of farmers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The monsoon is the lifeline of Indian agriculture. Most farmers depend on monsoon rain to water their crops because irrigation facilities are not available everywhere. Without adequate monsoon rain, crops fail and food prices rise.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the oldest mountain range in India?
questions.explanation_correct: The Aravalli Range in Rajasthan is the oldest mountain range in India and one of the oldest in the world. It stretches from Gujarat to Delhi. Over millions of years, it has been worn down and is now much shorter than the younger Himalayas.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Aravalli Range is the oldest mountain range in India (approximately 350 million years old). The Himalayas are the youngest (about 50 million years old). The Aravallis have been eroded over time and are now relatively low hills.

questions.question_text: The _____ Ocean lies to the south of India.
questions.explanation_correct: The Indian Ocean lies to the south of India. India is named after this ocean (or the ocean is named after India). The Indian Ocean is the third largest ocean in the world. India is a peninsula surrounded by the Arabian Sea, Bay of Bengal, and Indian Ocean.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Indian Ocean is to the south of India. The Arabian Sea is to the west and the Bay of Bengal to the east. India is the only country after which an ocean is named, highlighting its central position in the Indian Ocean region.

questions.question_text: Which state has Dispur as its capital?
questions.explanation_correct: Dispur is the capital of Assam, a state in northeastern India known for its tea gardens, Brahmaputra river, and one-horned rhinoceros. Many people confuse Guwahati (the largest city) with the capital, but Dispur is officially the capital.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dispur is the capital of Assam. Meghalaya's capital is Shillong, Manipur's is Imphal, and Nagaland's is Kohima. Assam is famous for its tea plantations and the Kaziranga National Park.

questions.question_text: Which river originates from the Gangotri glacier in the Himalayas?
questions.explanation_correct: The Ganga originates from the Gangotri glacier in the Himalayas (Uttarakhand). At its source, it is called Bhagirathi. It joins the Alaknanda river at Devprayag and is then called the Ganga. The Yamuna originates from the Yamunotri glacier.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Ganga originates from the Gangotri glacier. The Yamuna originates from Yamunotri. The Brahmaputra originates in Tibet. The Godavari originates from Trimbakeshwar in Maharashtra. Each river has a specific origin point.

questions.question_text: India has 28 states and 8 Union Territories.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. India currently has 28 states and 8 Union Territories. The most recent changes happened in 2019 when Jammu and Kashmir was reorganised into two Union Territories: Jammu and Kashmir, and Ladakh.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. India has 28 states and 8 Union Territories. States have their own elected governments, while Union Territories are mostly governed by the central government through appointed administrators.

questions.question_text: Kashmir experiences heavy snowfall in winter, while Kerala remains warm. Why is this?

options.text: Kashmir and Kerala are in different countries
Kashmir is in the mountains (high altitude) while Kerala is a coastal state near the equator
People in Kerala prefer warm weather
There is no difference in climate

questions.explanation_correct: Kashmir is at a high altitude in the Himalayas, which makes it very cold with heavy snowfall in winter. Kerala is a coastal state in the south, closer to the equator and at sea level, so it stays warm throughout the year. Location and altitude affect climate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both states are in India but have very different climates due to their geography. Kashmir is in the cold, high-altitude Himalayas, while Kerala is a warm, coastal state in southern India. Altitude and latitude are key factors.

questions.question_text: India's coastline runs along the:

options.text: Arabian Sea on the east and Bay of Bengal on the west
Arabian Sea on the west and Bay of Bengal on the east

questions.explanation_correct: India's western coastline is along the Arabian Sea, and the eastern coastline is along the Bay of Bengal. The Indian Ocean lies to the south. Together, India has a coastline of over 7,500 kilometres, one of the longest in the world.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Arabian Sea is on India's west coast and the Bay of Bengal on the east coast. A simple way to remember: Mumbai (west coast) faces the Arabian Sea, and Chennai (east coast) faces the Bay of Bengal.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an island Union Territory of India?
questions.explanation_correct: The Andaman and Nicobar Islands are an island Union Territory located in the Bay of Bengal. They consist of over 500 islands and are known for their beautiful beaches, coral reefs, and diverse tribal communities. Lakshadweep, in the Arabian Sea, is another island UT.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Andaman and Nicobar Islands are an island Union Territory in the Bay of Bengal. Chandigarh and Delhi are on the mainland. Puducherry is on the coast but not an island. Lakshadweep is the other island Union Territory.

questions.question_text: Which of the following pairs of state and capital is correct?
questions.explanation_correct: Kolkata is the capital of West Bengal. Maharashtra's capital is Mumbai (not Pune), Tamil Nadu's capital is Chennai (not Madurai), and Gujarat's capital is Gandhinagar (not Surat). Pune, Madurai, and Surat are important cities but not capitals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: West Bengal's capital is Kolkata. The other correct capitals are: Maharashtra - Mumbai, Tamil Nadu - Chennai, Gujarat - Gandhinagar. It is important not to confuse the largest city of a state with its capital.

questions.question_text: Rivers that originate in the Himalayas are different from peninsular rivers because they:

options.text: Are fed by both glacier melt and monsoon rain, so they flow throughout the year

questions.explanation_correct: Himalayan rivers like the Ganga and Brahmaputra are perennial (flow all year) because they are fed by melting glaciers and snow in summer and by monsoon rains. Peninsular rivers depend mainly on monsoon rains and may have reduced flow in the dry season.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Himalayan rivers flow year-round because they get water from both melting glaciers and monsoon rain. This makes them perennial. Peninsular rivers like the Godavari and Krishna depend mainly on monsoon rain and may have less water in summer.

questions.question_text: The state of _____ was divided into two Union Territories (Jammu and Kashmir, and Ladakh) in 2019.
questions.explanation_correct: In 2019, the state of Jammu and Kashmir was reorganised into two Union Territories: Jammu and Kashmir, and Ladakh. This reduced the number of states from 29 to 28 and increased Union Territories from 7 to 8.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Jammu and Kashmir was reorganised in 2019. Andhra Pradesh was divided in 2014 to create Telangana. Bihar was divided in 2000 to create Jharkhand. Madhya Pradesh was divided in 2000 to create Chhattisgarh.

questions.question_text: Myanmar borders India to the:
questions.explanation_correct: Myanmar borders India to the east. The states of Arunachal Pradesh, Nagaland, Manipur, and Mizoram share borders with Myanmar. Myanmar was formerly known as Burma. The border area is mountainous and covered with dense forests.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Myanmar (formerly Burma) is to India's east. Four northeastern states share borders with Myanmar: Arunachal Pradesh, Nagaland, Manipur, and Mizoram. Pakistan is to the northwest and Bangladesh is also to the east.

questions.question_text: Which physical division of India can be described as 'flat, fertile land formed by river deposits, ideal for growing crops'?
questions.explanation_correct: The Indo-Gangetic Plain perfectly matches this description. It is flat, made of fertile alluvial soil deposited by rivers, and is one of the most productive agricultural regions in the world. States like Punjab, Haryana, and Uttar Pradesh in this region produce large quantities of food grains.
